name: Blue Jay
description: Habitat: Blue jays inhabit deciduous and mixed forests, parks, and suburbs across eastern North America, nesting in trees and foraging from canopy to ground.
Diet: Omnivorous; they eat acorns, seeds, nuts, insects, and occasionally small vertebrates or eggs. They are known for caching acorns for later.
Behavior: Highly vocal and intelligent, blue jays mimic hawk calls, live in loose family groups, and display assertive territorial behavior at feeders.
Fun facts: Their striking blue color is structural, created by light scattering off feather microstructures rather than blue pigment.

name: Owl
description: Habitat: Owls occupy diverse habitats worldwide, from boreal forests and deserts to cities, often roosting in cavities or dense foliage.
Diet: Predominantly carnivorous; they hunt rodents, small birds, and insects using acute hearing and silent flight.
Behavior: Mostly nocturnal ambush predators with forward-facing eyes and flexible necks that allow up to 270Â° head rotation.
Fun facts: Specialized feathers reduce turbulence for near-silent flight, enabling stealthy approaches to prey.

name: Tiger
description: Habitat: Tigers range across forests, mangroves, and grasslands in Asia, requiring large territories with cover and water.
Diet: Obligate carnivores; their prey includes deer, boar, and other ungulates, taken through solitary stalk-and-ambush hunting.
Behavior: Territorial and largely solitary, tigers patrol scent-marked ranges and are strong swimmers that readily cross rivers.
Fun facts: A tiger's stripe pattern is unique to each individual, much like a human fingerprint.

name: Elephant
description: Habitat: Elephants inhabit savannas, forests, and marshes in Africa and Asia, migrating seasonally to track water and forage.
Diet: Herbivores; they consume grasses, leaves, bark, and fruit, spending many hours per day feeding to sustain their size.
Behavior: Highly social and matriarchal, elephants communicate with vocalizations and low-frequency rumbles that can travel long distances.
Fun facts: Their trunks contain tens of thousands of muscles, enabling delicate manipulation and powerful lifting alike.
